com.gcell.ibeacon.gcellbeaconscanlibrary

Class GCellBeaconScanManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.content.BroadcastReceiver
      • com.gcell.ibeacon.gcellbeaconscanlibrary.GCellBeaconScanManager

  • public class GCellBeaconScanManager
extends android.content.BroadcastReceiver

    KEY CLASS:: Manages the Bluetooth Low Energy scanning and returns nearby beacons

    The GCellBeaconScanManager Class

    The Class can be used to return all iBeacons within range regardless of UUID (when useBeaconRegions = False or only those determined by the supplied GCellBeaconRegion

    The GCellBeaconScanManager class is the central point for configuring the delivery of iBeacon and proximity based events to your app. You use an instance of this class to establish the parameters that determine when iBeacon is in range. A GCBeaconManager object provides support for the following iBeacon-related activities:

  • Monitoring the status of the Bluetooth on the users devices (on and off).
  • Handles all of the BlueTooth Low Energy set up, scanning and analysis or devices within range to identify if they are iBeacon type.
  • Checking and managing the appropriate Location permissions in Android.
  • Monitoring distinct beacon regions of interest and generating location events when the user enters or leaves those regions.
  • Reporting the range of nearby beacons.
  • If useBeaconRegions is false, all iBeacon devices within range are returned, regardless of their UUID.

    • Using Beacon Regions

    The library uses region-monitoring services to be notified when the user crosses a region-based boundary. Region monitoring here applies to beacon regions defined by GCellBeaconRegion. Regions represent the area a user can be in if they can see one or more beacons within range. You can use this capability to generate alerts or to provide other relevant information when the user enters or exits a beacon region. Rather than being identified by fixed geographical coordinates, a beacon region is identified by the deviceâ€™s proximity to Bluetooth low-energy beacons represented by GCelliBeacon. The identity of a beacon is defined by its proximityUUID, major, and minor properties. Beacon regions can be defined by their proximity UUID only, Proximity UUID and Major number or by the proximity UUID, Major and Minor Numbers. Please see the GCellBeaconRegion class for more detail. This gives developers flexibility in how they define iBeacon projects and infrastructure. The GCellBeaconRegion class has a number of constructors corresponding to these different definitions, but you can also automatically define a region based on the default GCell UUID.

    Region monitoring is used to detect boundary crossings of the specified region and those boundary crossings are used to perform related tasks. For example, upon approaching a stadium the user could be welcomed to the game and be sent a link to the latest team news. A beacon region is defined by one of three ways - its Proximity UUD, its UUID and Mjaor or its UUID, Major and minor number.

    Once a region or array of regions beaconRegions have been defined by appropriate initialisation of the GCellBeaconRegion class they can be added to search using setBeaconRegions(beaconRegions). Once added it is a simple case of calling startMonitoringForBeacons()

    Scanning for all iBeacon Devices

    An alternative method to using beacon regions is to just return all iBeacon devices within range, regardless of their UUID, Major and minor values. To accomplish this, set useBeaconRegions(false) and then call startScanningForBeacons()

    Getting the Discovered Beacons

    Implement the GCellBeaconManagerScanEvents Interface to get feedback from the beacon scan manager of any regions entered/exited and any ranged beacons. Scans are returned every 1s and any beacons not seen for x seconds are automatically removed form the list. The value of x defaults to 8s but can be customised using the setBeaconAutoRefreshRate() function.

    Monitoring the Bluetooth Status and Permissions

    The beacon scan manager registers to listen to the status of the Bluetooth hardware on the device. If it is not supported or switched off the manager will raise the appropriate events through GCellBeaconManagerScanEvents. The manager also checks relevant location permissions and is compatible with API 23 (Marshmallow). You need to override the onRequestPermissionsResult() in your main Activity, and simple pass its results to the handlePermissionResult() method. The manager will show an explanation screen before asking the user to grant permissions. The test on this can be configured using the setPermissionExplanationMessage() or switched off using the showPermissionExplanationDialog() functions. The requestCode used to request permissions defaults to 1 but can be set to any value using setPermissionRequestCode() allowing the main activity to request other permissions.

      • startMonitoringForBeacons

      • startScanningForBeacons

        public void startScanningForBeacons()
